Performance_Analysis_Report.intro:
This performance analysis report and tuning guide summarizes the overall health of the Informix database server over the specified period. The report provides valuable tips on how to fine-tune the performance of the system. The details shown in this report are based on the dbSonar performance tuning methodology described below.

Performance Tuning Methodology

Performance tuning based on dbSonar's performance analysis guide involves assessing performance of the operating system, database server, and application, and then conducting tuning on all levels. This multi-level approach ensures that you obtain satisfactory results from your system after performance tuning.

Database Server Tuning: At database server level, you must monitor table usage and/or fragmentation as well the system catalog information for the tables. The report provides guidelines about how to tune server configuration, optimize database table design, and update system catalogs to improve Informix optimizer efficiency.

Operating System Tuning: At the OS level, you need to monitor symptoms such as disproportionate utilization of CPU, memory, or disks. The report displays various resource utilization trends; use these to tune the OS configuration and improve performance.

Application Tuning: At the application level, you can monitor outstanding queries such as those with sequential scanning, high cost, or high frequency. The report suggests various recommended actions to optimize query performance.

Each of these tuning steps is described in further details along with guidelines and expert recommendations. Refer to the relevant section for more information.

UPDATE_STATISTICS_TABLE.header: Tables with Outdated UPDATE STATISTICS Information
UPDATE_STATISTICS_TABLE.intro: The following tables show out-of-date statistical information. Run the UPDATE STATISTICS command for these tables to improve performance:

INCOMP_STATISTICS_TABLE.intro: The following tables show incomplete data distributions. Run the UPDATE STATISTICS command (MEDIUM or HIGH mode) for these tables to improve performance:

HIGH_COST_SQL.intro:
The following table lists SQL statements with excessively high cost. Follow these guidelines to improve their performance:

  • Check whether statistical information used by the optimizer for the associated tables is current. Use the UPDATE STATISTICS statement to ensure up-to-date information.
  • Use optimizer hints or directives to tune SQL statements.
  • Set OPTIMIZATION LOW for queries that join multiple tables (5 or more).

FREQUENTLY_SQL.intro:
The following table lists SQL statements that occurred with high frequency. Follow these guidelines to improve their performance:

  • Check whether statistical information used by the optimizer for the associated tables is current. Use the UPDATE STATISTICS statement to ensure up-to-date information.
  • Use optimizer hints or directives to tune SQL statements.
  • Set OPTIMIZATION LOW for queries that join multiple tables (5 or more).

TABLE_DISTRIBUTION.intro: The following tables were found to have discontinuous physical storage of data. Re-organize the tables to increase I/O operation speed.

SEQSCAN_TABLE.intro: The following tables were found to have been accessed with repeated sequential scans. Try to improve performance with additional indexing.

BUSY_READ_TABLE.intro: The following tables were found to have heavy read activity. Try to improve performance with additional indexing and contiguous space allocation.

BUSY_WRITE_TABLE.intro: The following tables were found to have heavy write activity. Try to improve performance with additional indexing and contiguous space allocation.

LOCK_WAIT_TABLE.intro: The following tables were found to have lock waits. Improve performance by changing lock mode and granularity on tables with heavy access. Set lock mode to ROW for the following tables.

CPU_BUSY_RATE_TR.intro:
Heavy CPU utilization may affect system response time and cause performance degradation. However, high utilization for the CPU does not always indicate a performance problem. The CPU performs all calculations that are needed to process transactions. The more transaction-related calculations that it performs within a given period, the higher the throughput will be for that period. As long as transaction throughput is high and seems to remain proportional to CPU utilization, a high CPU utilization indicates that the computer is being used to the fullest advantage.

On the other hand, when CPU utilization is high but transaction throughput does not keep pace, the CPU is either processing transactions inefficiently or it is engaged in activity not directly related to transaction processing. CPU cycles are being diverted to internal housekeeping tasks such as memory management. You can easily eliminate the following activities to reduce CPU consumption:

  • Large queries that might be better scheduled at an off-peak time
  • Unrelated application programs that might be better performed on another computer

If the response time for transactions increases to such an extent that delays become unacceptable, the processor might be swamped; the transaction load might be too high for the computer to manage. Slow response time can also indicate that the CPU is processing transactions inefficiently or that CPU cycles are being diverted. When CPU utilization is high, a detailed analysis of the activities that the database server performs can reveal any sources of inefficiency that might be present due to improper configuration.

DISK_IO_BUSY_RATE_TR.intro: Disk I/O operations are usually the longest component of the response time for a query. Contiguously allocated disk space improves sequential disk I/O operations because the database server can read in larger blocks of data and use the read-ahead feature to reduce the number of I/O operations. It is thus important to monitor disk I/O utilization, keep track of I/O bottlenecks, and ensure that system response times remain within acceptable values.

OS_FREE_MEM_TR.intro: The free physical memory trend from the operating system shows the amount of physical memory that is available for use by a process. When the operating system needs to allocate memory for use by a process, it scavenges any unused pages within memory that it can find. If no free pages exist, the memory-management system has to choose pages that other processes are still using and that seem least likely to be needed in the short run. The free memory trend and the memory paging out trend (shown next) provide a picture of total memory consumption by the system.

OS_MEM_PAGE_IN_OUT_TR.intro:
Paging occurs when there is no free memory available for a process and the memory management system must find pages that are not likely to be used in the short run. These pages are copied to disk and freed for the process that needs free memory. Paging activity in memory must be monitored to make sure that the system has adequate memory and the CPU is not being overloaded with paging activity. Factors such as the number of page scans performed, the number of pages sent out of memory (paged out), and the number of pages brought in from memory (paged in) provide information about paging.

  • Paging out is a critical factor because the operating system pages out only when it cannot find pages that are free already.
  • A high rate of page scans causes increased CPU utilization and provides an early indicator that memory utilization is becoming a bottleneck.

BUFFER_RWS_CACHE_TR.intro: This trend chart shows percentage of all read operations that are read from the buffer cache without requiring a disk readand percentage of all write operations that are written into the buffer cache without requiring a physical disk write. The percentage of writes cached is an important measure of performance.

BUFFER_RWS_TR.intro: This trend chart displays the percentage of data reads and writes to and from the shared memory buffers. This trend chart is representative of the total activity occurring in the system and helps you decide the total amount of memory to be allocated for the buffer pool.

CKP_DUR_TR.intro:
During a checkpoint, the database server flushes all modified pages in the shared-memory buffer pool to disk and restores physical consistency. However, all transaction activities are suspended during checkpoints. Hence, checkpoint durations are usually required to be as short as possible to avoid delays for the end user.

The Informix database server uses either fuzzy or full checkpoints, with the checkpoint interval defined by the CKPTINTVL configuration interval. Checkpoints also occur when the physical log becomes 75 percent full. Fuzzy checkpoints take less time to complete than a full checkpoint because the database server flushes fewer pages to disk, and hence the database server can spend more time processing queries and transactions.Full checkpoints flush all dirty pages in the buffer pool to disk and consequently take longer to execute. The database server can skip a full checkpoint if all data is physically consistent when the checkpoint interval expires. Checkpoint occurrence also depends on the size and number of logical-log files.

Monitoring the checkpoint duration helps you estimate if the CKPTINTVL parameter as well as the parameters specifying the logical logs are configured optimally. Although the database server performs checkpoints automatically, you can initiate one manually or control checkpoint frequency. To reduce the amount of work required at a checkpoint (and consequently, its duration), use the BUFFERPOOL configuration parameter to lower the lru_min_dirty and lru_max_dirty values to enable LRU write before a checkpoint. LRU write operations cause only modified pages in individual LRU queues to be flushed.

DB_SEQ_SCAN_TR.intro: This trend chart shows the number of sequential scans that are requested in the database system at any given point of time. The high sequential scans may be caused by a missing index on a table or not enough a number of contiguous pages with each I/O operation.

DBSPACE_CHART.intro: This section of the report displays the I/O utilization of individual dbspaces in your system. Using this information, you can monitor the read/write activity in all the dbspaces, locate the dbspaces with high-activity tables and reorganize them if necessary, or monitor the logical/physical logspaces.

DBSPACE_PAGE_READ_TR.intro: This trend displays the total number of pages that are read from disk into the database system at any given point of time.

DBSPACE_PAGE_WRITE_TR.intro: This trend displays the total number of physical-log and logical-log pages in the database system that are written into disk at any given point of time.

LATCH_BUFFER_WAIT_TR.intro: The database server uses latches to control access to shared memory structures such as the buffer pool or the memory pools for the SQL statement cache. The number of times that threads had to wait to obtain a latch or the memory latch wait is a measure of system activity. A large number of latch waits typically results from a high volume of processing activity in which the database server is logging most of the transactions. As the DBA, you cannot configure or tune the number of latches. However, you can increase the number of memory structures on which the database server places latches to reduce the number of latch waits.

TOP_TB_READ_TR.intro: The trend chart displays the number of times that a table is read at any given point of time. If the number of times that a table is read is normally under a threshold value, it won"t be drawn on the trend chart.

TOP_TB_WRITE_TR.intro: The trend chart displays the number of times that a table is written at any given point of time. If the number of times that a table is read is normally under a threshold value, it won"t be drawn on the trend chart.

TOP_TB_LOCK_TR.intro: This trend chart displays the number of times that a table is locked at any given point of time. If the number of times that a table is locked is normally under a threshold value, it won"t be drawn on the trend chart. A table lock is more efficient than individual row locks, but it reduces concurrency for the table, which can affect performance. If the database server uses unusual large number of locks, you may need to examine the SQL statements to determine whether you should lock the table or use individual row or page locks.

DB_VIR_MEM_AU_TR.intro: The virtual portion of shared memory is expandable by the database server and can be paged out to disk by the operating system. As the database server executes, it automatically attaches additional operating-system segments, as needed, to the virtual portion. This trend chart displays the consumption of virtual memory by database processes.

VP_QUEUE_TR.intro: The trend chart displays the number of threads in the ready queue at any given point of time. A thread in the ready queue is ready to run when the current (running) thread yields. If the number of threads in the ready queue is high, it indicates that work is accumulating faster than the virtual processor can process, you may need to start additional virtual processors to distribute processing load.

DB_VP_BUSY_RATE_TR.intro: A virtual processor is a process scheduled by the OS to carry out basic tasks such as I/O, network management, queries, and so on. Multiple applications or threads that are accessing the server are split up into smaller virtual processors for faster and concurrent processing. The rate of usage of virtual processors on the database server is an indirect measure of the system performance. A high rate of virtual processing indicates a system with heavy load which might not have sufficient system resources to complete all transactions. By monitoring the number of virtual processors, you can keep an eye on CPU usage and add virtual processors to handle excess CPU load.

ACTIVE_LOCK_TR.intro: This trend chart displays the number of locks that are active in the database system at any given point of time. A lock can be applied to entire databases, entire tables, disk pages, single rows, or index-key values.

DB_COMMIT_TR.intro: This trend chart shows the number of transactions that are committed in the database system at any given point of time. The number of transactions committed in a given point of time provides an estimate of the transaction throughput which is a measure of the overall performance of your database system. The throughput can be affected by your host computer, the processing overhead in the application, the layout of data on disk, the degree of parallelism that both hardware and software support and the types of transactions.

DB_TRANS_TR.intro: This trend chart displays the number of database transactions that are active in a system at any given point of time. A high number of transactions indicates a higher rate of throughput.

DB_ROLLBACK_TR.intro: This trend chart presents the number of database transactions that are rollbacked at any given point of time.

LOCK_REQUEST_TR.intro: This trend chart shows the number of lock requests that are initiated at any given point of time.

ACTIVE_SQL_TR.intro: This trend chart shows the number of SQL statements that are active at any given time in the database system. A high number of SQL statements may indicate a high throughput but that is dependent on end-user response times and efficiency of operation.

NET_CONN_TR.intro: The network connection trend shows the number of connections established over the network and is a measure of total system activity. A high number of network connections indicates a busy system. Monitor this trend to keep track of periodic network activity and stay ahead of network problems.

NET_WAIT_STATUS_TR.intro: The network connection wait trend shows the number of connections that had to wait before a data request was carried out. These network waits impose an additional delay on end response times, thus slowing down performance.

ACTIVE_DB_CONN_TR.intro: This trend chart displays the number of database connections that are active at any given time of the day, thus enabling you to monitor database activity.

NET_RECE_Q_TR.intro: This trend chart shows the number of messages in the network receiving queue that are waiting to be processed.

NET_SEND_Q_TR.intro: This trend chart shows the number of messages in the network sending queue that are waiting to be sent out.
